I think I'm done testing I didn't find any strange behavior with the new `change_index` code. 

I found a very minor bug that I fixed with numpy not being imported as np and the numpy code not working because of this.(I fixed this by now)

content.raw:
Oh....I see now from the diff that you didn't add the resize of column 0, that was already there. I'm guessing that was introduced at some point recently, but that is the line that is the issue with the colour selector boxes (to be clear, the issue appears when you double click the colour square to bring up the colour selection drop down). I'm happy to merge as is and fix myself if you like, but I plan on resizing column 1 (which was fine) and not resizing column 0 (at least for the moment)

So I'm happy to merge once you finish whatever testing yo're doing!

![Bildschirmfoto 2017-06-27 um 22.07.15.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgkE5Ke/images/926213567-Bildschirmfoto%202017-06-27%20um%2022.07.15.png)
update.title: Shutter Times

content.raw:
Great! Interface looks good (except for one minor issue I'll mention below)

I'm reviewing the code now (rather than the interface):

* The inner loop in `add_shutter_times` I suspect is inefficient (may only show up in testing if you have shutters on an NI card that has a high sample rate analog out ramp?). I suspect the following (untested) code is more efficient since it's implemented in numpy. It's very, very untested though so you might want to double check I haven't got an off by one error!

```Python
change_indices = np.where(y_values[:-1] != y_values[1:])[0]
change_indices += 1 # use the index of the value that is changed to
change_values = zip(x_values[change_indices], y_values[change_indices])
change_values.insert(0, (x_values[0], y_values[0])) # insert first value
```

* The width of the colour column in the list of shots is now too narrow (because it is being auto resized I think). At least on my machine, I can't see the colour boxes in the drop down list (when trying to change the plot colour) due to the scrollbar. If you make the column wider by hand, you can see the colour boxes.  
* `create_plot` and `update_plots` seem to share some very similar code. You might want to consider factoring it out into a separate function to avoid duplication. The main argument for this is that means you don't forget to update the code in both places when making a change! (In the future we're very likely to forget the code exists twice!) I mention this because it looks like there is still some left over code in `create_plot` to do with the colour of markers matching the plot colour which I think you've now undone?

‌
content.html:
Great! Interface looks good (except for one minor issue I'll mention below)

I'm reviewing the code now (rather than the interface):

  • The inner loop in add_shutter_times I suspect is inefficient (may only show up in testing if you have shutters on an NI card that has a high sample rate analog out ramp?). I suspect the following (untested) code is more efficient since it's implemented in numpy. It's very, very untested though so you might want to double check I haven't got an off by one error!
change_indices = np.where(y_values[:-1] != y_values[1:])[0]
change_indices += 1 # use the index of the value that is changed to
change_values = zip(x_values[change_indices], y_values[change_indices])
change_values.insert(0, (x_values[0], y_values[0])) # insert first value
  • The width of the colour column in the list of shots is now too narrow (because it is being auto resized I think). At least on my machine, I can't see the colour boxes in the drop down list (when trying to change the plot colour) due to the scrollbar. If you make the column wider by hand, you can see the colour boxes.
  • create_plot and update_plots seem to share some very similar code. You might want to consider factoring it out into a separate function to avoid duplication. The main argument for this is that means you don't forget to update the code in both places when making a change! (In the future we're very likely to forget the code exists twice!) I mention this because it looks like there is still some left over code in create_plot to do with the colour of markers matching the plot colour which I think you've now undone?

‌

content.raw:
Nice to see that the runviewer pull requests get some attention again! :slight_smile:

* ~~I don't get this exception even if I delete the runviewer group in older shots of ours could you provide a traceback? If it is caused by the backwards compatibility code for our old shots I could remove that and just add it to our labs version of runviewer.~~ 

    Update: was able to reproduce the bug caused by a missing 'calibrations' group will fix



    Update 2: Should be fixed now


* This is changed now so, that checkboxes are disabled for all not selected shots. If a shot gets enabled and doesn't have shutter times there the checkbox for shutters stays disabled with the tooltip "This shot doesn't contain shutter delays".

    Update: changed tooltip to "This shot doesn't contain shutter markers" as it can also be caused by a shot having no shutters in it and other stuff


* Added `resizeColumnToContents()` to deal with this

I think we can change the coloring some time later if we really dislike it.
content.html:
Nice to see that the runviewer pull requests get some attention again!

  • I don't get this exception even if I delete the runviewer group in older shots of ours could you provide a traceback? If it is caused by the backwards compatibility code for our old shots I could remove that and just add it to our labs version of runviewer.

    Update: was able to reproduce the bug caused by a missing 'calibrations' group will fix

    Update 2: Should be fixed now

  • This is changed now so, that checkboxes are disabled for all not selected shots. If a shot gets enabled and doesn't have shutter times there the checkbox for shutters stays disabled with the tooltip "This shot doesn't contain shutter delays".

    Update: changed tooltip to "This shot doesn't contain shutter markers" as it can also be caused by a shot having no shutters in it and other stuff

  • Added resizeColumnToContents() to deal with this

I think we can change the coloring some time later if we really dislike it.

update.description:
This change adds green and red markers to shutter plots indicate the physical open/close time.
This feature has been discussed in #12 and partly in #5.

![Bildschirmfoto 2017-06-27 um 22.07.15.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgkE5Ke/images/926213567-Bildschirmfoto%202017-06-27%20um%2022.07.15.png)
update.title: Shutter Times

content.raw:
Ok, let's start with this pull request since I think it's the easiest to get merged!

Comments so far:

* There is a exception raised if you load a shot that has no shutters because the "shutters" group in the HDF5 file doesn't exist
* Similar to this, while you catch and ignore the exception if the shot has not been compiled with the latest version of labscript (that saves the open state to the connection table), the check box is still visible. This confused me for quite a while (as I didn't know why the shutter markers were not showing up until I went hunting through the code!). If there are no shutter markers, we should disable the checkbox (and probably have a tooltip that explains why - either legacy shot file that doesn't support shutter markers, or no shutters).
* The width of the Shutter column seems quite wide by default. You might want to consider shrinking it if it's easy (though to be honest, if you just want to leave it we can clean this one up in another pull request since the rest of the interface defaults to silly sizes anyway).

Given the "beta" nature of runviewer in general, I think I'm happy to merge once the backwards compatibility issues are fixed (as above). I'm still not sure I'm 100% happy with the interface/colouring, but I don't think there's much point messing around with it now. Maybe once all of the current changes are merged in I'll find the time to play around and see if I can propose something better.
content.html:
Ok, let's start with this pull request since I think it's the easiest to get merged!

Comments so far:

  • There is a exception raised if you load a shot that has no shutters because the "shutters" group in the HDF5 file doesn't exist
  • Similar to this, while you catch and ignore the exception if the shot has not been compiled with the latest version of labscript (that saves the open state to the connection table), the check box is still visible. This confused me for quite a while (as I didn't know why the shutter markers were not showing up until I went hunting through the code!). If there are no shutter markers, we should disable the checkbox (and probably have a tooltip that explains why - either legacy shot file that doesn't support shutter markers, or no shutters).
  • The width of the Shutter column seems quite wide by default. You might want to consider shrinking it if it's easy (though to be honest, if you just want to leave it we can clean this one up in another pull request since the rest of the interface defaults to silly sizes anyway).

Given the "beta" nature of runviewer in general, I think I'm happy to merge once the backwards compatibility issues are fixed (as above). I'm still not sure I'm 100% happy with the interface/colouring, but I don't think there's much point messing around with it now. Maybe once all of the current changes are merged in I'll find the time to play around and see if I can propose something better.

content.raw: Ok so I changed the way shutter markers work. They now get added for each shot but are hidden. If the user toggles a newly added checkbox they are shown. Since this is now a individual per shot thing I decided to drop the shot colors and make the shutter colors red and green again. Does this solve the coloring concerns you had @pstarkey?
content.html: Ok so I changed the way shutter markers work. They now get added for each shot but are hidden. If the user toggles a newly added checkbox they are shown. Since this is now a individual per shot thing I decided to drop the shot colors and make the shutter colors red and green again. Does this solve the coloring concerns you had @pstarkey?

This change adds green and red markers to shutter plots indicate the physical open/close time.

![Bildschirmfoto 2017-06-27 um 22.07.15.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BgkE5Ke/images/926213567-Bildschirmfoto%202017-06-27%20um%2022.07.15.png)

content.raw:
1. will do.
2. Yeah things get confusing but your proposed changes wouldn't help. As you would lose the ability to tell open times and close times apart. Also you would not be able to tell markers from shutter markers without at least one other plot. I really think this (and markers) can't be done right in the same plot. Things are confusing enough already when viewing more than one shot (at least on the digital outs), maybe we should make markers and shutter markers a one shot only feature as well?
content.html:
1. will do.
  2. Yeah things get confusing but your proposed changes wouldn't help. As you would lose the ability to tell open times and close times apart. Also you would not be able to tell markers from shutter markers without at least one other plot. I really think this (and markers) can't be done right in the same plot. Things are confusing enough already when viewing more than one shot (at least on the digital outs), maybe we should make markers and shutter markers a one shot only feature as well?

content.raw:
Two things:

1. It seems a bit inefficient to delete all the lines and then re-add them in `update_plots()`. The other code in that method tries to only modify plots that need changing. I think it would be worth trying to make it more efficient.
2. I again have concerns with colours. This interface looks great if you only have one shot. If you have more than one shot visible, you aren't going to be able to tell what is going on. It will be even more confusing if the trace for shots 2 and 3 are red and green, and thus colour match half of the shutter lines respectively. I think we need to solve the UI design for this, and for the marker colours in pull request #9 before they can be merged. Perhaps the easiest solution is just to make the markers and shutter lines colour match the trace **if** there is more than one trace selected.
content.html:
Two things:

  1. It seems a bit inefficient to delete all the lines and then re-add them in update_plots(). The other code in that method tries to only modify plots that need changing. I think it would be worth trying to make it more efficient.
  2. I again have concerns with colours. This interface looks great if you only have one shot. If you have more than one shot visible, you aren't going to be able to tell what is going on. It will be even more confusing if the trace for shots 2 and 3 are red and green, and thus colour match half of the shutter lines respectively. I think we need to solve the UI design for this, and for the marker colours in pull request #9 before they can be merged. Perhaps the easiest solution is just to make the markers and shutter lines colour match the trace if there is more than one trace selected.
